pull.title: Change new constants in txdb.h to int64_t
pull.body:
A shift overflow was happening when using these to check against in init.cpp.
Fixes #3702.

repo.name: bitcoin
repo.description: Laanwj's Bitcoin Core fork - see README.md on "readme" branch

events.message:
Change new constants in txdb.h to int64_t

A shift overflow was happening when using these to check against in init.cpp.
Fixes #3702.

issue.title: Shift overflow bug
issue.body:
clang is telling me:

```
init.cpp:782:41: warning: signed shift result (0x100000000) requires 34 bits to represent, but 'int' only has 32 bits
```

Git blame points the finger at:

```
82e96006 src/init.cpp      (Philip Kaufmann          2014-02-16 22:00:12 +0100  780)     if (nTotalCache < (nMinDbCache << 20))
```

events.body:
Maybe it'd be better to change the constants to bytes (move the shifts to the constants instead of at the comparison site in init.cpp).
Showing in MiB is only UI/commandline-level. Regardless, you need shifts at either place.

Automatic sanity-testing: PASSED, see http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/ad54a9b83f416d6bbd84eaaec55bf1e6f56308b1 for binaries and test log.
This test script verifies pulls every time they are updated. It, however, dies sometimes and fails to test properly.  If you are waiting on a test, please check timestamps to verify that the test.log is moving at http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/current/
Contact BlueMatt on freenode if something looks broken.
I'm sorry this happened, but my compiler didn't give any warning. Also I'm not the one who introduced the shifts, that was sipa ;), I'm more comfortable with 4 \* 1024 \* 1024 for example.

@Diapolo Using multiplications instead of shifts would have resulted in the same problem. No hard feelings, this caught me unaware as well, in the 2010's we're casually veering outside the bounds of 32-bit types even for memory sizes.
